title: Wisconsin Criteria for Maxillofacial Trauma CT
description: Clinical decision rule to predict the need for CT imaging after maxillofacial trauma. This validated tool helps emergency physicians determine which patients with facial injuries require computed tomography to detect significant fractures while avoiding unnecessary radiation exposure in low-risk patients.

parameters.name: high_energy_mechanism
parameters.description: High-energy mechanism of injury (motor vehicle collision, fall >3 feet, assault with object, sports injury)

parameters.name: facial_deformity
parameters.description: Visible facial deformity or asymmetry on inspection

parameters.name: malocclusion
parameters.description: Dental malocclusion or inability to open mouth normally

parameters.name: facial_numbness
parameters.description: Facial numbness or altered sensation (especially infraorbital distribution)

parameters.name: palpable_step_off
parameters.description: Palpable step-off deformity of facial bones

result.name: ct_recommendation
result.description: Recommendation for CT imaging based on Wisconsin Criteria

ranges.interpretation: No high-risk criteria present. CT imaging is not indicated. Clinical observation and symptomatic treatment are appropriate. Consider plain radiographs if clinically indicated for specific concerns.
One or more high-risk criteria present. CT imaging is indicated to evaluate for significant facial fractures. Proceed with facial CT with coronal and sagittal reconstructions.

references: Koller KE, Sabatino MJ, Skalski KA, et al. Implementation of clinical decision rules for emergency department patients with facial trauma. AEM Educ Train. 2018;2(4):269-275. doi: 10.1002/aet2.10103

Dreyer SJ, Wolf SJ, Mayglothling J, et al. Clinical policy: critical issues in the evaluation and management of patients presenting to the emergency department with acute blunt facial trauma. Ann Emerg Med. 2023;82(1):94-114. doi: 10.1016/j.annemergmed.2023.03.032
Hopper RA, Salemy S, Sze RW. Diagnosis of midface fractures with CT: what the surgeon needs to know. Radiographics. 2006;26(3):783-793. doi: 10.1148/rg.263055031
Hashim H, Iqbal S. Chronic pain after facial trauma. Br J Oral Maxillofac Surg. 2010;48(4):270-274. doi: 10.1016/j.bjoms.2009.07.024
formula: Presence of any high-risk criteria (high-energy mechanism, facial deformity, malocclusion, facial numbness, periorbital swelling, diplopia, palpable step-off, or epistaxis) indicates need for CT imaging. Absence of all criteria suggests CT is not necessary.
notes: Validated clinical decision rule for facial trauma imaging
Helps reduce unnecessary radiation exposure in low-risk patients
High sensitivity for detecting clinically significant facial fractures
Does not replace clinical judgment in complex cases
Consider patient age, medical comorbidities, and social factors
High-energy mechanisms include MVCs, falls >3 feet, assaults with objects
Low-energy mechanisms include simple falls, minor altercations
Facial numbness particularly important for orbital floor fractures
Malocclusion may indicate mandibular or maxillary fractures
Diplopia suggests orbital fracture with muscle entrapment
Rule designed for adult patients in emergency department setting
Not validated for pediatric patients or penetrating trauma
Consider ophthalmology consultation for suspected orbital injuries
Plain radiographs have limited utility in facial trauma
CT with bone windows and reconstructions preferred imaging modality
